docs.lead_paragraph: St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center and Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center announced yesterday that they were actively negotiating a partnership, which, if the talks succeed, would create by far the largest hospital in New York City and one of the largest in the country. While no agreement has been reached, officials at both hospitals said the goal of their negotiations was to merge and create the largest health care system in the city, delivering specialty, primary and long-term care in both hospital and out-patient settings.

headline.main: 2 Big Hospitals In New York City Pursue a Merger

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Jan. 7 front-page article on the "infertility market" was strikingly provincial, implying that all infertility centers worth discussing are in the New York area. There are high-quality infertility programs with pregnancy rates greatly exceeding those you cite.

headline.main: Fertility Treatment Has Good Success Rate;Smaller, Better Clinics

docs.lead_paragraph: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation said late yesterday that it intended to transform itself into three publicly traded companies, joining a wave of corporations that are taking steps to give more value to shareholders.

headline.main: Dun & Bradstreet to Split Into 3 Public Companies

docs.snippet: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation said late yesterday that it intended to transform itself into three publicly traded companies, joining a wave of corporations that are taking steps to give more value to shareholders.

docs.lead_paragraph: Michele and Jerry Cler have invested an enormous amount of time, anguish and money in their three-year effort to have a baby. The Clers have depleted their savings, borrowed against their house here and run up their credit card balances, all to pay for $34,070 worth of infertility treatments. For months they have fought an uphill battle to get their health insurer, which has paid $8,688 of the bills so far, to cover more of their expenses.

headline.main: Couple Now Has No Savings, More Debt and Little Hope of Having a Baby

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael Plaut answered the telephone in his home in Scarsdale, N.Y., hungry for information that he and his wife, Stephanie, needed if they were to get on with their lives. The call confirmed his worst fear: the pregnancy test was negative. The Plauts sobbed, held each other and then had a glass of Scotch.

headline.main: Infertile Couples Forge Ties Within Society of Their Own

docs.lead_paragraph: The idea of discarding the elaborate Federal tax system in favor of a simple flat tax is about to go from an obscure academic discussion among economists to a full-throated debating issue in the Presidential campaign.

headline.main: Flat Tax, Once Obscure Idea, Is Set to Enter Campaign Debate

docs.snippet: The idea of discarding the elaborate Federal tax system in favor of a simple  flat tax is about to go from an obscure academic discussion among economists to  a full-throated debating issue in the Presidential campaign.

docs.lead_paragraph: Returning to the merger trail after the collapse last month of its $1.89 billion plan to acquire Health Systems International Inc., Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the life and health insurance unit of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company for about $380 million. With the deal, Leonard Schaeffer, chairman of Wellpoint, could try to convert a million Massachusetts Mutual customers from traditional fee-for-service health coverage to Wellpoint's main business -- health maintenance organizations and other managed-care networks of doctors and hospitals.

headline.main: After Deal Fails, Wellpoint Finds Another Target

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton's proposal to balance the budget in seven years, rather than narrowing the differences between him and Republicans in Congress, shows how big the gap is. In a hastily prepared evaluation, the Congressional Budget Office said on Saturday that Mr. Clinton's latest plan would eliminate the deficit in the year 2002.

headline.main: The Bottom Line May Be the Same, but All the Other Items Appear to Be Out of Sync
headline.kicker: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE ISSUES
